<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 460, 88]]<|/det|>
A student determines the density of sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 589, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows a beaker with a mark at the \(250 \text{cm}^3\) level.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 128, 571, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 259, 534, 277]]<|/det|>
<mark>[a]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 146, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 291, 833, 308]]<|/det|>
Estimate the volume of water \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) that the beaker would hold when filled to the top.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 320, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>W</sub> = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[916, 322, 923, 339]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 146, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 885, 370]]<|/det|>
The student uses string and a metre rule to determine the circumference \(c\) of the beaker.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 377, 917, 400]]<|/det|>
\[c = \frac{21.3\mathrm{cm}}{15.5\mathrm{cm}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
Explain briefly how to use the string and the metre rule to determine the circumference \(c\) as accurately as possible. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 655, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 146, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 564, 700]]<|/det|>
The student measures the height \(h\) of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 711, 180, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 711, 707, 728]]<|/det|>
Show clearly on Fig. 1.1, the height \(h\) that he should measure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 711, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 740, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
His reading is \(h =\) 9.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 770, 181, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 770, 740, 789]]<|/det|>
Calculate the external volume \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the beaker using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 794, 544, 824]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{h c^{2}}{12.6}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 910, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>B</sub> = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 910, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 828, 89]]<|/det|>
The student measures the mass of the beaker on a balance, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 181, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 100, 688, 119]]<|/det|>
Write down the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the beaker, to the nearest gram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 127, 598, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 237, 534, 255]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
The student fills the beaker to the top with dry sand. He measures the mass \(m\) of the beaker containing the sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 333, 918, 356]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... $724 \text{g}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 367, 181, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 367, 843, 386]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass \(m_{\mathrm{S}}\) of sand in the beaker. Use the equation \(m_{\mathrm{S}} = (m - m_{\mathrm{B}})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 438, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
<form>m_{\mathrm{S}} = .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 467, 178, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 467, 640, 486]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the sand using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 488, 536, 521]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{m_{\mathrm{S}}}{V_{\mathrm{B}}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 329, 541]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 621, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
<form>ρ = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 648, 146, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 648, 920, 695]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 653, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 583, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the ray-trace sheet that the student uses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 128, 885, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 785, 532, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
• The line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of a plane mirror. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Continue the normal so that it reaches the bottom of the ray-trace sheet. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 133, 630, 151]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) 5.0 cm below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and parallel to \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 165, 529, 182]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{X}\) where \(\mathbf{CD}\) crosses \(\mathbf{NL}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 196, 620, 213]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line \(\mathbf{EF}\) 5.0 cm below \(\mathbf{CD}\) and parallel to \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 227, 524, 244]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{Y}\) where \(\mathbf{EF}\) crosses \(\mathbf{NL}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 243, 920, 261]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 273, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 272, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
Draw a line 7.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(\theta_{1} = 20^{\circ}\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 144, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
The student places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) . Suggest a suitable distance \(x\) between the pins for this type of ray-trace experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 364, 920, 382]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 146, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
The student views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 2.1. She places pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
She places pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) so that pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) , all appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown on Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 180, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 505, 594, 523]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(a\) from \(\mathbf{X}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 536, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 567, 180, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 567, 594, 585]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(b\) from \(\mathbf{Y}\) to \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 597, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 628, 183, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 628, 304, 647]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\frac{a}{b}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 657, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{a}{b} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure using an angle of incidence \(\theta_{2} = 40^{\circ}\). She records the new values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 112, 917, 135]]<|/det|>
\[a = \frac{4.2\mathrm{cm}}{} \quad 8.3\mathrm{cm}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 158, 917, 180]]<|/det|>
\[b = \frac{8.3\mathrm{cm}}{} \quad 2\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 193, 384, 215]]<|/det|>
Calculate the new value \(\frac{a}{b}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 218, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{b} = \frac{}{} \quad [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 269, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the two values of \(\frac{a}{b}\) can be considered to be equal in this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 146, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
A student carries out this experiment with care. Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 395, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 376, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows the circuit used.

The student measures the current \(I\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 918, 472]]<|/det|>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 861, 777, 888]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the resistor using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 911, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<form>R_{1} = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The student disconnects the voltmeter from terminal B and connects the voltmeter to terminal C. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> He places the sliding contact S at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from C. He records, in Table 3.1, the reading on the voltmeter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 166]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\), \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(100.0 \text{cm}\). His readings are shown in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 180, 541, 197]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 207, 670, 370]]<|/det|>
\(l/\mathrm {cm}\)\(V/V\)
20.00.4
40.00.8

80.01.5

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 596, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates springs made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 826, 120]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the extension of springs made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 420, 151]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 346, 181]]<|/det|>
boss, clamp and stand

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 182, 245, 197]]<|/det|>
metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 197, 445, 213]]<|/det|>
springs made from different metals

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 420, 228]]<|/det|>
selection of loads with hangers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 907, 259]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 324, 290]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 510, 321]]<|/det|>
• write a list of suitable metals for the springs

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 517, 352]]<|/det|>
• draw a diagram of the set up you would use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 549, 383]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how to carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 398, 487, 414]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 918, 461]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 672, 492]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 87]]<|/det|>
